content: The "Student Disciplinary Fairness Act of 2017" aims to address the issue of juveniles entering the criminal justice system for minor school infractions. Common behavioral issues often lead to suspension, expulsion, or incarceration, with zero-tolerance policies contributing to increased juvenile incarceration rates. Research shows that incarcerated juveniles face challenges in completing school, developing human capital, and are more likely to reoffend as adults. The "Student Disciplinary Fairness Act of 2017" establishes the Office of School and Discipline Policy within the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention to reduce juvenile incarceration resulting from school-related activities. The Office aims to prevent juveniles from developing criminal records due to school behavior and to decrease the number of incarcerated juveniles. The Office of School and Discipline Policy, in collaboration with other agencies, collects data on juvenile arrests for school rule violations, promotes alternatives to detention, and examines the impact of school resource officers on juvenile arrest rates. The Office of School and Discipline Policy collects data on juvenile arrests for school rule violations and examines the impact of school resource officers on arrest rates. The School Discipline Policy Grant Program, outlined in SEC. 603, aims to address juvenile arrests for school rule violations and evaluate the role of school resource officers in arrest rates. The Director may grant funds to States, local governments, and educational agencies to reduce juvenile arrests for school rule violations. Applicants demonstrating progress towards this goal receive preference in funding allocation. Students are arrested and incarcerated for violations of school rules or policies, as determined by the Director to further the purpose described in section 601(b). The text defines key terms related to schools and law enforcement, such as 'school', 'school resource officer', 'local educational agency', and 'juvenile student'. It also authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2017 and 2018 to implement the provisions outlined in the document. SEC. 4. CONDITIONS FOR STATES TO RECEIVE ``COPS ON THE BEAT'' GRANTS. Section 1702(c) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include new requirements for State or local government applicants regarding the administration of juvenile justice in accordance with the US Constitution and specific amendments. The amended Section 1702(c) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 sets new requirements for State or local government applicants in administering juvenile justice, ensuring that arresting officers have probable cause specific to the juvenile and that arrested juveniles receive adequate procedural due process, including notice, legal representation, and protections against self-incrimination. The amended Section 1702(c) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 mandates new requirements for State or local government applicants in juvenile justice, including ensuring probable cause for arrests, providing procedural due process, legal representation, protections against self-incrimination, and the right to cross-examine witnesses. Probation contracts for juveniles must be easily understood and cannot lead to incarceration for school rule violations. The Attorney General is granted authority to access records related to juvenile justice under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. Additionally, a Department of Education grant program is established. The Secretary of Education will provide grants for training school personnel in de-escalation techniques to address student behavior issues and prevent law enforcement referrals. Eligible entities must submit an application demonstrating compliance with federal school discipline data reporting requirements. The Secretary of Education will provide grants for training school personnel in de-escalation techniques to address student behavior issues and prevent law enforcement referrals. Eligible entities must comply with federal school discipline data reporting requirements, including providing complete information to Department of Education surveys. Elementary and secondary schools can only receive assistance from one eligible entity during a grant period. Definitions include "eligible entity" as a State, unit of general local government, or juvenile justice agency. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums may be appropriated for fiscal years 2017 and 2018 to implement the provisions outlined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
